The bacterium is capable of forming endospores, which are highly resistant structures that allow the organism to survive in harsh environmental conditions.

Phylogenetically, Bacillus sonorensis is closely related to other members of the Bacillus cereus group, which includes several well-known species such as Bacillus cereus and Bacillus anthracis. However, Bacillus sonorensis can be distinguished from these closely related species based on its unique biochemical and genetic characteristics.

Bacillus sonorensis is considered an environmental bacterium and has been found in various soil and dust samples. While it is not known to be a human pathogen, some Bacillus species can cause opportunistic infections in immunocompromised individuals. Further research is needed to fully understand the ecological roles and potential applications of Bacillus sonorensis.
